PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Kenyon, Florence A. (Mrs. Henry Joshua)
Address: 1892, Kenyon, Mrs. Florence
Lemberg

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ...........1875
Where did you set up housekeeping? ..............................................In the Dominion of Canada
Where had you been living before that? .............................................In England
For how many people did you prepare meals? .................................About 11 people
How far was it to your nearest store? ................................................About 1 mile
How often would a visit be made to the store? .................................About twice a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? ..................Salt, coffee, dried fruit, oatmeal.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ....................Path, milled wheat flour
What quantities did you buy? ...............................................................About 40 pounds
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ..........About $3.50
How much did you use graham flour? ................................................About 10 pounds
Was flour milled locally? .................................................................Yes
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ...............About $1.50
What other grain products did you use? ..............................................Cornmeal
Other? ..............................................................................................Farina
Did you grind your own what for porridge? ......................................We took it to a mill
How did you grind it? .................................................................We had a crusher & we used it a lot

Apricot and also in bread.

16. TRADITIONS AND CUSTOMS

During the early years, I remember very well how we celebrated Christmas. We always had a big dinner on Christmas Eve, followed by a smaller breakfast on Christmas morning. We would exchange gifts and cards, and there was always a lot of singing and caroling.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner, and snacks) for the earliest year you can remember. Include the names of the family members who ate at the table, along with their ages at the time.

The menu for December 25th, 1895:

Breakfast: Pancakes, bacon, and toast.

Dinner: Roast beef, mashed potatoes, carrots, and green beans.

Supper: Bread pudding, apple pie, and coffee.

Sometimes, we would have an extra course of dessert, such as a fruit tart or a cake.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in your parents' home? Give details.

I served my first Christmas dinner in my parents' home in 1999. It was a special occasion because it was my daughter's birthday, and we invited her friends over for a party. We cooked a roast turkey, mashed potatoes, and cranberry sauce, and we had a chocolate cake for dessert.

19. Were you ever refused to almost starvation level living on one locally produced food? Give details.

No. We always had plenty to eat. The lack of fresh meat was hard to get used to, but we never went hungry. We would often prepare a meal of porridge and quail for dinner when unexpected company arrived, but our guests were always well-fed. At another time of remember, provisions were made. The harvest for eggs to feed incorporated Company.
16. **TRADITIONAL CHRISTMAS DINNER**

   During the family gathering, the food was prepared in the house. The family would gather around the table for dinner.

   17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner, and supper) for the entire family.

   18. Describe how the family would celebrate Christmas Day.

   19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

   Yes. We always had plenty to eat. The lack of fresh meat was hard to get used to, but flour was always plentiful. During the war years, we ate mostly plain, homemade bread and porridge for dinner.

   20. Prepare a meal of porridge and tell me about it.

   When unexpected Company arrived, I put on a few extra pounds. At another time, I remember making the ham for our first Christmas dinner in my parents' home in 1949 at which time, we were still living in the same house.

   21. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in your parents' home?

   I have a record of a Christmas dinner in my parents' home in 1949 at which time, we were still living in the same house.

   22. Did you ever have to go without food during the war years?

   No. We always had plenty to eat. The lack of fresh meat was hard to get used to, but flour was always plentiful. During the war years, we ate mostly plain, homemade bread and porridge for dinner.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

As far as I can remember, we used to get meat from a local butcher, to go along with the vegetables. We would also have milk delivered daily. In the early days, we had to keep the milk cold for the day. In the early days, we had to have a big pot going in the heat of summer to cook a meal. Nowadays, we can have meals cooked with electricity. Large batches of bread had to be baked regardless of heat, whereas we can now buy bread brought into town daily. There was not the variety of foods that there is today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I did not buy bread until the summer of 1942, the same year I started buying butter.

I have always grown my own vegetables, and still do so. In 1902, we bought canned salmon, and canned tomatoes. Until we retired from the farm in 1942, we always had our own supply of meat either salted or canned. About 1914, we started buying such things as canned corn, cornflakes.
